comment.author: 74804504@N00
comment._content: In 1942 Ohio State Route 74 ran from Cincinnati Eastward toward Batavia. Mount Gilead is North of Columbus. A map of Ohio from 1942 showing State Route 74 can be found here. Route 74 seems to end around Peebles, OH. Mt Gilead is on the 1942 map in its present location and does not appear to have Route 74 going through it. I could be wrong, but I think this picture would have to have been taken between Cincinnati and Peebles if it was taken along Route 74 in Ohio in 1942 or 1943. In 1962 Ohio Route 74 was rename Ohio Route 32 when Interstate 74 was built. There are several sections in Cincinnati still called "Old State Route 74"

comment.author: 7875245@N08
comment._content:
Nice information, some of it I did not know. I live close to and travel on Old 74 everyday. It runs through the Glen Este, Sommerville and Mt Carmel area out towards Batavia.

My Dad never ever got use to calling St Rt 32 any thing but St Rt 74.
I could be wrong but I think Gov. Rhodes was the one who changed it to 32 from 74 when it was redone.

comment.author: 74804504@N00
comment._content: Thanks. Its amazing what google and wikipedia can come up with. This photographer has another picture from the Library of Congress's collection on flickr. It was also initially identified as being taken in Mt Gilead, but looks like it was later identified as being taken in Lincoln, Nebraska. Here's the link: http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2179931106/. Hopefully he got the state right on this photo.

comment.author: 53291780@N06
comment._content:
C.A. Long
Submitted by Charles David Long on Fri, 11/27/2009 - 11:57pm.

C.A. Long was my great-grandfather. The building in the photo was constructed in 1896 for the International Order of Odd Fellows. The Lodge used the top story for its meetings and rented the ground floor. Charles Anderson Long (1859-1939) moved his grocery business from Williamsburg, Ohio, to Mount Orab in 1931.

The business before C.A. rented it in 1931 was a shop that assembled horse buggies (see second photo below). Charles rented the building for his grocery business. His son Julius Paul Long had taken over the grocery in 1939 after C.A.'s death. My father, J.P. Long Jr., bought the grocery in 1968 and continued the business on the corner of 74 & 68 until 1972, when it moved north of town on State Route 68. It closed in 1988.

The Marvel was the movie theater in town about one block south on Route 68. It is now being used as the local Masonic Lodge. Route 74 was renamed State Route 32 and then eventually Tri-County Road. The IOOF building was sold when the Lodge closed (1990s?) and is now being used as a women's clothing store.

comment.author: 50016613@N06
comment._content:
The building is still standing on the north-west corner of "Main and High" in Mt. Orab Ohio.
You can use Google street view to see it here: 39.027888,-83.919853
"Main ST" is now Tri-County Road as mentioned by a relative of the original store owner above.
The building can be recognized by the distinctive half-round windows and now-boardedup stone archway along the East side.
